trans-unit.source: Azure uses an xml file to define all VNets available to a subscription.
trans-unit.target: Azure uses an xml file to define all VNets available to a subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can download this file, and edit it to modify or delete existing VNets, and create new ones.
trans-unit.target: You can download this file, and edit it to modify or delete existing VNets, and create new ones.

trans-unit.source: In this document, you will learn how to download this file, referred to as network configuration (or netcgf) file, and edit it to create a new VNet.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you will learn how to download this file, referred to as network configuration (or netcgf) file, and edit it to create a new VNet.

trans-unit.source: Check the <linkText>Azure virtual network configuration schema</linkText><title></title> to learn more about the network configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Check the <linkText>Azure virtual network configuration schema</linkText><title></title> to learn more about the network configuration file.

trans-unit.source: To create a VNet using a netcfg file using PowerShell, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VNet using a netcfg file using PowerShell, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Get-AzureVnetConfig cmdlet to download the network configuration file by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Get-AzureVnetConfig cmdlet to download the network configuration file by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output under the command.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output under the command.

trans-unit.source: Open the file you saved in step 2 above using any XML or text editor application, and look for the element. If you have any networks already created, each network will be displayed as its own element.
trans-unit.target: Open the file you saved in step 2 above using any XML or text editor application, and look for the element. If you have any networks already created, each network will be displayed as its own element.

trans-unit.source: To create the virtual network described in this scenario, add the following XML just under the element:
trans-unit.target: To create the virtual network described in this scenario, add the following XML just under the element:

trans-unit.source: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Set-AzureVnetConfig cmdlet to upload the network configuration file by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Set-AzureVnetConfig cmdlet to upload the network configuration file by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output under the command, you should see Succeeded under OperationStatus.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output under the command, you should see Succeeded under OperationStatus.

trans-unit.source: If that is not the case, check the xml file for errors.
trans-unit.target: If that is not the case, check the xml file for errors.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Get-AzureVnetSite cmdlet to verify that the new network was added by running the command below.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure PowerShell console, use the Get-AzureVnetSite cmdlet to verify that the new network was added by running the command below.

trans-unit.source: Notice the output with the properties of your new VNet.
trans-unit.target: Notice the output with the properties of your new VNet.
